Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2011 01:28AM - edited Jan 16, 2011 01:33AM by mathteacher Eclaire, You are at the best place to be--before surgery! I wouldn't suggest letting your radiation oncologist anywhere near your nodes. Radiating nodes virtually guarantees lymphedema. I don't know what he meant by tweaking your treatment. Can you get more details? Chemo is temporary. Radiation damage is forever. I have a smart friend who is a lawyer who made her surgeon sign the consent form that she would take no more than three nodes. She had seen her mother suffer with lymphedema and she wasn't going to risk it if she could help it. If you have one positive node they are saying it trumps the Oncotype DX?  It depends on the philosophy of the surgeon. The guidelines are only guidelines. Can you get your surgeon to read the Guiliano study? Do you have the NY Times version? Surgeons don't like reading complex stuff, they like to cut. Ask any nurse :)
